page.title: 18ECOLOGY
page.content: In this farming area,the fields are much the same as they have been for years. Dividing the fields, and lining the lanes are drystone Derbyshire walls. They have no cement or mortar to hold them together, but have stood for hundreds of years. Not many people can build them now. Although they have the appearance of being thrown together, they are carefully laid. Most farming land is grazing,meadow and arable. It is sad to see the stubble being burnt polluting the air. Over a hundred years ago nothing was wasted. The farmer had the corn, the gleaners came and gathered in their aprons loose ears from the stubble,then the geese were turned into the field to fatten up for Michaelmas.Now the combine harvester reaps the grain and little tongues of fire take the rest.
